amber: Fossilized tree resin. Can be melted down to reinforce items.
animalSkull: A large hollowed out, bleached animal skull, suitable for crafting into a provisional helmet.
arrow: A projectile to be fired from a bow, crafted with an arrowhead and feather to control flight.
stoneArrowhead: Crafted from stone and to be used in the crafting of arrows. Could also be used as a carving implement.
pileOfAsh: The powdery remains of burned matter.
barkLeggings: Rudimentary leg armor, crafted from strong tree bark and secured with string.
barkShield: A makeshift shield, used to block incoming attacks, made with tree bark and wrapped with string.
barkTunic: Tree bark chest armor bound together with string.
bone: A heavy, sun-bleached animal bone, suitable for rudimentary combat, gathering, or crafting into more useful items.
branch: A typical tree branch, useful for a variety of crafts or stoking a fire.
cactusSpines: Thin, long spikes, suitable for crafting into makeshift needles.
cobblestoneFlooring: Primitive flooring created by placing stones in an organized pattern, filling any gaps.
cookedMeat: Adequately heated meat, safe and ready for consumption.
earthworm: A live wriggling insect, effective for bait or eating on its own.
feather: Some bright white plumage from an avian creature.
fertilizer: A rich mixture of organic materials and chemicals, suitable for combining with soil to create a fertile soil.
waterskinOfSeawater: A waterskin full of seawater, not suitable for drinking without desalination.
firePlough: A fire making device which uses a stick and groove method to create heat through friction.
flowerSeeds: Dried flower seeds which can be planted to grow flowers.
fossil: A carbonized fossil of a species long since extinct.
goldCoins: Shiny, golden coins, from a lost civilization unknown to you.
goldenChalice: A large, ornate, and resplendent chalice.
goldenRing: A golden ring, most likely used as a sign of wealth and power.
goldenSword: An ornate, but soft sword, forged from solid gold. Not suitable for combat due to its softness.
grassSeeds: Small dried grass seeds. Can be planted to grow grass.
ironOre: Unprocessed, raw iron ore. Can be smelted into ingots.
kindling: A gathering of small twigs and tree matter. A requirement for starting a fire.
largeRock: A rather large rock, handy for crafting many tools and devices.
leafBedroll: A provisional bed with poor insulation and scratchy half-dried leaves, used for sleeping or resting.
leatherHide: A fresh leather hide, stripped from an animal and de-furred.
leaves: A handful of foliage used as compost, to stoke a fire, or as tinder when dried.
limestone: A mineral-rich rock that can be ground into a powder. Useful for metal and glass production.
log: A sturdy piece of wood, useful for construction or as a fuel for a fire.
mortarAndPestle: Used for grinding and crushing, made from smooth stones.
whiteMushrooms: Edible, long lasting mushrooms. They appear safe to consume.
nopal: A de-spined cactus fruit, filled with refreshing liquid and nutrition.
peat: A dried mass of sponge-like plants, great for fire fuel and composting.
sandstone: A soft, malleable rock, useful for construction and tool making.
pileOfGravel: A large pile of damp stone and sand.
pileOfSand: A large pile of moist sand, useful for making glass when refined.
woodenArrow: A provisional wooden projectile to be fired from a bow. Crafted with a feather to control flight.
stoneAxe: A simple stone axe used for chopping wood or as a carving implement.
bandage: A tattered piece of fabric, used to staunch wounds and prevent infection.
wovenFabric: A makeshift piece of fibrous tissue, woven together into fabric.
cactusNeedle: A needle from a cactus plant, useful in crafting smaller, more intricate items.
stoneShovel: A digging tool made of stone, used to collect different materials from the ground or to route water.
woodenSpear: A makeshift, easy to craft hunting weapon. Makes for an ideal ranged weapon.
suture: A sharp needle tool with an attached thin string, used to sew and close gaping wounds.
raft: A small, simple boat; a quicker alternative to swimming. Effective for traversing large expanses of water.
rawMeat: A raw, bloody chunk of meat. Cooking is recommended before consumption.
redBerries: Lush, ripe berries, plucked from a tree or bush.
spottedRedMushroom: An odd looking, foul smelling mushroom.
rope: A thick, twisted piece of cordage, useful for heavy-duty binding.
sapling: A young, fertile tree, suitable for replanting.
seaweed: A stringy mass of sea plants. Can be used as cordage or eating in desperation.
sharpGlass: A semi-opaque shard of glass, formed after melting sand down.
sharpRock: A sharpened rock, useful for crafting, tool making, and carving when required.
skullcap: A hollowed-out animal skull, useful as a provisional helmet.
smoothRock: A round, smoothed rock, useful for many crafts.
soil: A pile of moist dirt. The heavy smell of earth permeates your nostrils when holding it.
stoneSpear: A hunting weapon crafted with a stone head, suitable as a throwing weapon.
stones: A mass of small rocks. Can be used for throwing or crafting.
stoneWall: A series of interlaced stones and rocks, shaped into a vertical wall structure. Can be built to keep enemies out.
string: Woven fabric; the cornerstone of all crafting materials, mainly used for binding.
strippedBark: A strong, fibrous shaving from a branch, useful for making cordage.
tannedLeather: A durable, treated piece of leather. Used in crafting armor and other tools.
tannin: A natural treating agent. To be applied on hides to create tanned leather.
thistleSeeds: Small hard seeds, used for growing thistle plants.
treeBark: A tough, dense chunk of bark, broken off from a tree.
treeFungus: A semi-hard chunk of fungus, grown from a tree and possibly edible.
vine: A long, winding tree vine, suitable for cordage.
twigs: A small pile of sticks and tree limbs.
waterskin: A portable water container, made from stitched leather.
woodenPole: A long piece of wood, carved and shaved down into a smooth rod from a branch or log.
peatBandage: A fabric bandage combined with peat as an effective antiseptic.
bow: A bent wooden pole with a shorter string tied to both ends. The tension of the string is used to fire arrows.
bowDrill: An advanced fire starting device. Uses the string on a bow to rotate into the wood, reducing much effort.
fishingNet: A checkered weave of string with weights on each corner, used to trap and catch fish.
rawCod: Slimy to the touch, but healthy and delicious to eat. Can be cooked for a better meal.
cookedCod: A seared, well cooked cod, ready to consume and enjoy.
stoneCampfire: A grouping of rocks shaped into a ring to contain a fire.
vineWhip: A makeshift weapon made simply with tree vines wrapped together.
pileOfSnow: A melting snow pile. Useful to drink in desperate need, but be quick!
barkTorch: A torch wrapped and bound by stripped tree bark, providing natural oils to increase the life of the torch.
litBarkTorch: Provides light to your surroundings when equipped and can also be used to start other fires.
handDrill: A rudimentary fire making tool which uses a stick and another piece of wood. Both hands are used to twist the stick against wood, making friction to create an ember for the fire.
smallBag: A leather pouch used for holding a few items, carried at your waist, reducing encumbrance.
shale: A brittle but sharp carving implement.
sharpenedBone: A sharp bone, useful for carving other objects.
grindstone: A coarse rock useful for sanding, sharpening, and repairing other items.
rawFishSteak: A raw piece of fish, cut into a fillet. Good to eat as is, but is tastier cooked.
cookedFishSteak: A cooked fish fillet, seared on the outside and delicious.
waterskinOfDesalinatedWater: A waterskin full of freshly desalinated seawater.
boatPaddle: A makeshift boat paddle used with boats and rafts, or combat if in dire need.
bullBoat: A boat made from leather hides and framed with curved wooden poles. Used to travel to new, far away lands.
refinedSand: A finely ground sand, useful in making glass.
spyglass: An improvised, short-range telescope, which can be used to see slightly further away in any direction when equipped.
flask: A glass container which can be heated to use for desalination, a process used to make seawater drinkable.
rawClay: A soft, formable mud. Suitable for building materials, tool-making, and more.
rawClayBlowpipe: An unfired clay blowpipe used in glassblowing. Unusable until it has been fired.
clayBlowpipe: A sturdy blowpipe used for glassblowing.
leatherBelt: Made from tanned animal hide, cut, wrapped, and stitched together to tie around the waist.
leatherTunic: A leather garment which provides protection for the torso.
leatherBoots: Malleable yet tough foot protection, crafted from tanned animal hide.
leatherCap: A hat made of leather, double layered for extra sturdiness.
leatherGorget: A circlet of leather, bound in two, stitched together and used as neck protection.
leatherPants: Basic leather leggings with just enough padding to provide some leg protection.
leatherGloves: Leather-bound hand protection, crafted from tanned animal hide.
stoneFurnace: An enclosed structure made of stone, which traps in the heat to keep a long-lasting, high-temperature fire.
sandstoneKiln: Similar to a furnace, but constructed with sandstone and in a way that allows for proper heat distribution for crafting glass and clay items.
ironTongs: Durable iron tongs used to grab hot items, protecting your hands from damage.
talc: A very chalky mineral, only useful in its powder form.
talcumPowder: Chalky and abundantly absorbent to the touch. An agent required for casting of advanced metals.
sandCastFlask: A mold for casting metal into any shape, made with green sand.
lens: Glass formed into a partially convex shape. It allows focusing sunlight into a single location, creating enough heat for a fire.
plantRoots: A tangled mess of roots, with earth still hanging from the tips.
lockPick: An improvised needle and prong that should be strong enough to pick a lock or two.
boneNeedle: A thin, hard, sharp needle, carved from bone.
pineapple: A juicy, ripe pineapple, loaded with vitamins and thirst-quenching attributes.
tatteredMap: An old torn map covered with drawings and scribbles, a bit hard to make sense of on first glance.
coal: A black and brittle mineral, staining anything it touches, but useful as fuel.
wroughtIron: A heavily oxidized and unpurified form of iron, used in the forging of brittle tools, weapons, and armor.
limestonePowder: A white, mineral-dense powder used in glass tempering and the purifying of metals.
ironIngot: A solid brick of iron, ready to be formed or melted and cast in many ways.
backpack: Crafted with leather, it's suitable for holding many items on your back, reducing overall weight.
rottenMeat: Acrid decomposing animal tissue. You would not want to eat this, but can be used in compost.
stoneHammer: A rudimentary stone hammer, braced on the end of a pole with string. Used for gathering and repairing.
rawChicken: A small, plump and de-feathered chicken carcass, ready for cooking.
cookedChicken: A well cooked chicken, ready to consume and sure to satisfy.
stoneAnvil: A solid stone anvil. Used in the production of metal armor, weapons, and tools.
woodenChest: A large wooden container that can fit many items while placed on the ground. Foods will decay slower within it.
ironSword: A strong, sharp blade designed for thrusting and slashing.
ironBreastplate: Durable, armor worn over the torso. One could take a serious beating while wearing this.
ironBoots: Heavy iron plated boots, shielding your feet from damage.
ironHelmet: Iron plated headgear designed to withstand heavy blows.
ironGorget: A round metal brace worn around the neck and over the shoulders.
ironGreaves: Iron leggings; to be strapped on and function as leg protection.
ironGauntlets: Iron gloves designed to be protective and durable, while maintaining as much flexibility as possible.
ironShield: A large and heavy iron shield, used for blocking projectiles or melee attacks.
sandstoneWall: A constructed wall built from mined sandstone.
sandstoneFlooring: A group of sandstone bricks, placed in a grid to be used as flooring.
spiderSilk: A delicate but strong strand of silk, produced by a spider. Can be used as cordage.
animalFat: A gelatinous shaving of animal fat, slimy to the touch. Useful as a rendered fuel.
animalFatTorch: A torch; wrapped in rendered animal fat, producing a long-lasting light source.
clayFlakes: Dried shavings of clay. Created by shaving clay and drying over a period of time.
greenSand: A form of malleable sand made with clay, used to make molds for metal casting.
oldInstructionalScroll: A tattered sheet of paper with some roughly scribbled instructions and diagrams.
slimeGelatin: A lump of slime gelatin which jiggles upon your touch. Can be used to preserve food, or melted down and used as glue.
glue: A natural form of glue that can be used to bind and reinforce items.
cookedSpiderMeat: Crispy spider meat. Not the best texture or flavor, but contains the more edible portions of the deceased arachnid.
spiderMeat: A spider's fleshy innards. It's hard to stomach, even when cooked. Try not to think about what you're eating.
ironLockPick: A pair of iron picks and wrenches, durable enough to pick the most adept of locks.
rottingVegetation: A stinking mash of organic plant matter, now usable as compost. Unless you want to risk eating it.
wildOnion: A strong smelling and tasting plant, packed with nutrients and vitamins.
ironHammer: A strong hammer with an iron head, perfect for shaping and repairing items.
ironSpear: A polearm with a strong pointed tip forged from iron.
ironShovel: A heavy iron digging implement, lifting and breaking through even the toughest gravels and soils.
ironDoubleAxe: An axe with a forged, double sided head, ideal for both combat and gathering.
ironPickaxe: A robust mining implement, with a blade forged from iron.
inkstick: A hardened brick of ink, used for drawing and painting.
coconut: A fibrous and heavy fruit. Difficult to consume, but packed with plenty of caloric-dense coconut meat and milk.
palmLeaf: A large leaf from a palm tree. The strong inner fibers of the leaf are perfect for cordage.
offal: A mound of organs, tissue, and other undesirable portions of an unlucky animal.
boneFragments: A bundle of bones from a small vertebrate. Some cracked, others shattered. The pieces are quite sharp.
litPoleTorch: A wooden pole that has been lit on fire. Not suitable for long journeys in the darkness.
cotton: A downy bundle of opened cotton seeds, the ideal solution for spinning thread and making fabrics.
cottonSeeds: Unopened, plantable cotton seeds, not yet revealing their white, soft interiors.
cottonFabric: A soft piece of cloth spun from cotton.
bonePole: A smooth cudgel crafted from a large bone.
tourniquet: A hard stud twisted together with a string. Used to twist around a bleeding wound to stem the flow of blood.
wroughtIronPickaxe: A dual-headed mining implement. One head is heavy and blunt, the other, spiked to cut through rock with ease.
wroughtIronDoubleAxe: A dual-bladed axe which can provide enough slashing damage for both combat and gathering.
wroughtIronShovel: A shovel with an angled, pointed head, useful for digging and water routing.
wroughtIronSpear: A polearm with pointed head, crafted from wrought iron. Used in melee or thrown in combat.
wroughtIronHammer: A large mallet crafted from wrought iron. Useful for repairing and sometimes gathering.
wroughtIronLockPick: A set of picks and wrenches made from wrought iron, used for picking and unlocking locked devices.
wroughtIronShield: A sturdy wrought iron shield, made by bending large sheets of metal into shape.
wroughtIronGauntlets: Intricate and sturdy, these wrought iron gloves fit snugly on your hands.
wroughtIronGreaves: Wrought iron leggings, strapped and padded around the legs to reduce most damage.
wroughtIronGorget: A molded piece of metal, used to protect the area around the neck and shoulders.
wroughtIronHelmet: Using a barbute design, this iron helmet shields the head from most kinds of attacks.
wroughtIronBoots: Wrought iron footwear. Heavy and made specifically for protecting feet and lower legs.
wroughtIronBreastPlate: A large wrought iron chest plate, worn over the torso.
wroughtIronSword: A long, sharpened blade fitted into a solid hilt and forged from wrought iron. A good, strong weapon.
woodenWall: A sturdy set of bound logs, forming a protective wall that can be placed.
woodenFlooring: Wooden floor boards; planed to equal height and length.
woodenDoor: A door crafted from long wooden planks with large wooden hinges. Can be opened and closed when built.
fishingRod: A flexible, smooth wooden rod with a string line and sharpened hook. Used for fly fishing.
messageInABottle: An old cloudy bottle with an unidentified object contained inside.
pileOfCompost: A mix of decaying organic matter, full of chemical nutrients and great for growing plants with when combined with soil.
meltedAmber: Warmed amber resin; used to create a hardened bind when cooled on to an object.
woodenShavings: A dry bunch of wooden shavings, used to ignite kindling when starting a fire.
deadfall: A large, flat rock, propped up with a stick. Once set, anything that triggers it will be crushed or injured from the falling rock.
snare: A short pole pushed into the ground with a string attached. Designed to ensnare creatures in its slipknot.
waterskinOfMedicinalWater: A soothing mixture of plants and roots. Used to heal poisons and illnesses.
charcoalBandage: A cloth bandage, coated in charcoal and used for its natural antiseptic and anticoagulant properties.
woodenTongs: A pair of simple wood tongs, used to pick up hot objects without injury.
wroughtIronTongs: A pair of tongs, forged from wrought iron. Used to lift hot objects without injury.
sheetOfGlass: A cloudy tempered piece of glass. Practical for many optical tools and other simple devices used to harness the sun.
solarStill: A still that collects condensation and filters it into in a hole beneath the glass, desalinating the water and draining it into a container.
stoneWaterStill: A hollowed out rock with a stone lid. It's used to desalinate water by boiling it and then collecting the steam into a separate container.
sundial: A stone timepiece that uses the location of the sun or moon to show the approximate time of day or night.
litAnimalFatTorch: A bright burning, pleasant smelling torch. Made with a pole and long lasting, rendered animal fat.
sinew: Strong and flexible animal tissue. Commonly used for making bows or simple cordage.
shortBow: A bow designed for powerful shots at close range.
longBow: Nearly as tall as the average person, this bow is designed for maximum range.
compositeBow: An expertly crafted bow, designed for both velocity and force.
waterskinOfPurifiedFreshWater: A full waterskin of fresh, safe-to-drink water.
waterskinOfUnpurifiedFreshWater: Unpurified and possibly hazardous water. It is recommended you purify the water before drinking.
glassBottle: A transparent vessel with a cork for containment. Used for collecting water.
cork: A small cork plug. Crafted from rubbery tree bark; it can be used to contain liquids in bottles and other containers.
glassBottleOfSeawater: Filled to the top with seawater. While seawater is technically drinkable, it will not reduce your thirst.
glassBottleOfDesalinatedWater: A bottle filled with clear seawater that has been processed to remove the salt content.
glassBottleOfMedicinalWater: A bottled concoction of herbs and nutrients. Used to cure thirst, poisons, and other ailments.
glassBottleOfPurifiedFreshWater: glass bottle of purified fresh water
Potable, and safe to hydrate yourself with. The water has been purified reducing any toxins and unsafe bacteria.
glassBottleOfUnpurifiedFreshWater: glass bottle of unpurified fresh water
A bottle containing water that is likely unfit to drink. It will quench your thirst, but may have negative side-effects until it's purified.
wroughtIronArrow: An arrow with a wrought iron arrowhead. The shaft of the arrow is long and is fletched with feathers.
ironArrow: An arrow tipped with a high quality iron arrowhead. Fletched with feathers to stabilize flight and accuracy.
stoneBullet: A basic stone projectile for slings and firearms. Smooth and more or less spherical in shape.
wroughtIronBullet: A small ball of wrought iron, used as ammunition for slingshots or firearms.
ironBullet: A strong, forged iron bullet. Used as sling or firearm ammunition.
leatherQuiver: A leather-bound, back-mounted container designed to hold arrows; however, other items will also fit inside as well.
ectoplasm: A ghostly, weightless fluff of misty goo, strangely self contained and quickly evaporating.
magicalEssence: An odd transparent powder with organic and ethereal materials. This magical matter may be used on items to affix magical properties on to them.
woodenFence: A section of wooden fencing, constructed from three logs and held together with horizontal beams.
creatureIdol: A mass of animal organs, crudely shaped into some kind of figure. It smells awful and emits an odd humming noise, and appears to attract creatures.
cordedSling: A thick piece of cordage, wrapped and bound with a slot made for a projectile. Used to swing ammunition, increasing throwing range.
leatherSling: A sling crafted from tanned leather. Designed to hold a projectile to be thrown at an increased velocity.
wroughtIronArrowhead: Forged with wrought iron, this arrowhead is used to craft an arrow. In dire need, it could also be used for carving.
ironArrowhead: An expertly forged iron arrowhead, used to create arrows. Alternatively can be used to carve if necessary.
hammock: A comfortable place to sleep, although not too sturdy. Crafted by bound cordage and usually hung off of the ground.
cottonBedroll: A soft and downy sleeping mattress, rolled up for ease of carrying. Can be used to sleep or rest very comfortably.
featherBedroll: A bedroll made with soft feathers and wrapped in fabric. Used for resting and sleeping in comfort.
rawTaintedMeat: A piece of bad-smelling meat, possibly diseased or tainted with parasites. Possible to consume, but could be deadly.
cookedTaintedMeat: A piece of discolored meat, cooked to kill possible toxins, but possibly still unsafe for consumption.
stoneKnife: A sharpened piece of stone, carved into a blade, with a handle for support. Can be used as a weapon, gathering tool or to carve.
rawBlindfish: An odd looking fish with no eyes. Very slimy to the touch.
cookedBlindfish: While the source of the food is a bit suspect, after being cooked, it appears to be more palatable.
pemmican: A ball of dried ground meat. With a long shelf life, this is the ultimate survival food. For the best benefits, prepare it with animal fat.
preparedPemmican: A seasoned mound of dried ground meat, fried and cooked with fat for maximum flavor and caloric content.
sail: A large piece of fabric, woven together to be attached to a mast. Used on a sailboat to propel it along the sea.
sailboat: A large one-man boat. Used to traverse large expanses of water and for travel back to civilization.
egg: A brown colored egg, laid by a chicken. Can be eaten as is, or cooked for a tastier meal.
boiledEgg: A moist, delicious boiled egg. Great tasting and packed with protein.
grassBlades: Long and almost sharp to the touch. These semi-dried grass blades are perfect for cordage, string making, and tinder when dried.
niter: A natural mineral, ground up to be used as a preservative or for other chemical applications.
saltpeter: A ground mineral, to be used as a natural food preservative. If combined with other minerals, it can be combustible.
blackPowder: A highly combustible powder, made up of a combination of minerals.
flintlockPistol: A long range, high damage pistol. Requires black powder and bullets to fire.
giblets: A batch of cooked animal organs. Considerably repugnant, but nutritious and filling.
explosiveTrap: A mound of leaves used to conceal a volatile explosive powder. Stepping on it will trigger a small explosion.
skeletalMageWand: A mysterious, gnarled staff with a twinkling red gemstone attached to the end.
rawClayJug: A formed and sculpted jug molded from raw clay. Requires a cork and a kiln to be fired and hardened.
clayJug: A fully hardened clay jug with a cork. Used to hold water.
clayJugOfSeawater: Unfiltered seawater, held in a clay jug. Unsuitable to drink in its current form but could be desalinated.
clayJugOfDesalinatedWater: Potable, safe-to-drink water. The water in this clay jug has gone through the desalination process.
clayJugOfMedicinalWater: A clay jug containing medicinal water, used to cure and soothe certain ailments while also replenishing your thirst.
clayJugOfPurifiedFreshWater: clay jug of purified fresh water
A clay jug filled with fresh, purified water. Can be used to quench your thirst.
clayJugOfUnpurifiedFreshWater: clay jug of unpurified fresh water
A clay jug full of natural, fresh water. Although it is drinkable, further purification is recommended.
rawClayBrick: A soft piece of raw clay, molded into a rectangle. Ready to be fired inside a kiln.
clayBrick: A hardened clay brick, used in the building of structures such as floors and walls.
clayBrickWall: A wall made from clay bricks, set into a typical skewed, grid-like fashion to increase durability.
clayBrickFlooring: Flooring crafted from clay bricks. Could be used as decoration or as part of a building.
pineappleSeeds: Small brown seeds that can be planted to grow into pineapple plants.
berrySeeds: Black seeds that will grow into a berry bush, given enough time and care.
cactiSeeds: These appear to be cactus seeds. Can be planted to grow cacti or eaten.
vineSeeds: Seeds to grow vines. Can be eaten if desperate, but they do not contain any significant nutrition.
paperSheet: A large piece of paper. It appears to contain many recycled fibers. Suitable for drawing on with ink.
paperMold: A mold used for making paper. Contains a screen that holds wet recycled fibers to dry and press into flattened, usable paper.
flowerPetals: The petals of a yellow flower. Only useful in creating medicinal tonics, or ingesting directly if food supply is low.
thistles: The flowering bulb of a thistle plant. Filled with a bitter but nutritious milk.
drawnMap: A paper sheet, scrawled with geographical landmarks and features. Used to approximate a location when read.
tatteredShirt: A once fine piece of a clothing, now torn and tattered.
tatteredPants: Brown colored pants, now reduced to shorts from distress and wear.
woodenGate: A gate crafted from long wooden planks with small wooden hinges. Can be opened and closed when built.
poisonIvyLeaves: Causes irritation to the touch; these leaves of three do not belong on your person.
poisonIvySeeds: Bright green, soft seeds, used to plant to grow into poison ivy.
wroughtIronChest: A spacious container built from wrought iron that can store many items. Foods will spoil slower inside of it.
ironChest: A large iron chest that is both roomy and sturdy. Foods contained within will decay at a slower rate.
tallGrassSeeds: Long dried grass seeds. Can be planted to grow a longer type of grass.
acorn: A hard tree nut with a cupule that can grow into a sapling when planted.
spiderEggs: Soft and squishy to the touch. These small silken eggs contain arachnid life inside.
tailFeathers: A fluffy clump of white feathers, removed from an avian creature's backside.
bigRedBerry: An abnormally large, plump red berry, full of luscious nutrition.
venomGland: The venom producing gland of a snake, still filled with some immobilizing venom.
ornateWoodenChest: A decorative wooden container gilded with symbols inlaid into the wood.
rollOfRedCarpet: A rolled up piece of red carpet, suitable for making a comfortable living space or welcoming important guests.
ornateCape: A red and gold stitched cape, which drapes the back and fastens at the neck. Worn as a status symbol.
fireBladder: An oddly shaped organ from a firebreathing creature. Hot to the touch; it appears to contain a deadly chemical reaction inside.
goldenKey: A large and decorative key forged from gold.
woodenSword: A sturdy blunt sword, crafted from wood with a sharp piercing point. Most useful for sparring practice.
clayKiln: Similar to a furnace, but constructed with clay and in a way that allows for proper heat distribution for crafting glass and clay items.
clayCampfire: A grouping of clay bricks shaped into a ring to contain a fire.
clayFurnace: An enclosed structure made of clay bricks, which traps in the heat to keep a long-lasting, high-temperature fire.
clayWaterStill: A carved out clay brick with a lid. It's used to desalinate water by boiling it and then collecting the steam into a separate container.
sandstoneCampfire: A grouping of sandstone shaped into a ring to contain a fire.
sandstoneFurnace: An enclosed structure made of sandstone, which traps in the heat to keep a long-lasting, high-temperature fire.
sandstoneWaterStill: A hollowed out piece of sandstone with a lid. It's used to desalinate water by boiling it and then collecting the steam into a separate container.
stoneKiln: Similar to a furnace, but constructed with rocks and in a way that allows for proper heat distribution for crafting glass and clay items.
wroughtIronAnvil: An anvil made from wrought iron with a wooden base. Useful for metalworking.
ironAnvil: A sturdy iron anvil. Used in the production of metal armor, weapons, tools, and more.
mageRobe: An ancient tattered robe, once owned by a spell casting foe.
orbOfMalign: A strange spherical orb that gives off a shimmering radiance on your touch. It appears to hum as you hold it.
animalClaw: A sharp claw from an animal. A perfect animal by-product for using as a needle.
animalPelt: The remains of an unlucky skinned animal. Can be used as a makeshift garment or dismantled into the hide and fur separately.
animalFur: A large clump of animal fur and hair. Could be used as tinder in a situation where wood is not available.
scales: Dried and hardened scales from a reptilian creature. Can be used as a rudimentary fabric.
sharkFin: Not much more than a trophy, this carved dorsal fin remains slippery and rubbery to the touch.
rawReptileMeat: A grainy piece of edible reptile flesh. Generally not safe to consume without being cooked due to bacteria.
cookedReptileMeat: A grilled piece of reptile meat. The look and texture could almost be passed as chicken.
tentacles: A slimy, wriggling appendage from an unlucky cephalopod. Can be eaten, but with some force due to the rubbery unpleasant texture.
cookedTentacles: Although, still springy to the touch, this cooked cephalopod appendage can be stomached much easier than if raw.
wormMeat: Essentially a mash of worm innards, almost ground up into a paste. Definitely not the most appetizing, but can be cooked for better flavor.
cookedWormMeat: A cooked patty of worm meat. Unappetizing to think about, but can provide as a good source of needed nutrition.
stonePickaxe: A primitive stone pickaxe used for mining into rock or as a stopgap blunt weapon.
wroughtIronAxe: An axe forged out of wrought iron, primarily used for lumberjacking and carving.
ironAxe: An iron-forged axe used in wood chopping. Its sharp end can be used for crafting and carving.
fertileSoil: A rich soil, suitable for setting down to attempt to grow plants on.
stoneHoe: A rudimentary tilling and gardening tool, used to break up soil for more successful growth of plants.
wroughtIronHoe: A long pole with a wrought iron metal blade attached to the end. Used to till the ground for planting seeds.
ironHoe: A long-handled gardening tool with a blade on the end, forged from iron. Used to till soil for better plant growth.
lavaBeetleHelmet: An extremely hardened and fire resistant helmet, sourced from the carcass of a fallen lava beetle.

woodenDoor: A sturdy door, used to keep unwanted creatures out.
woodenFence: A set of panels, usually used to keep creatures inside.
woodenWall: A wall crafted by connecting wooden logs together.
clayBrickWall: A wall made from fired clay bricks.
sandstoneWall: A robust wall created from sandstone.
stoneWall: A hardy wall built from rocks.

wildOnion: A single onion planted in to the ground.
pineapplePlant: A large spikey plant, with a ripened pineapple fruit within.

berryBush: A small bush, bearing small amounts berries.
yellowFlowers: A grouping of bright yellow flowers.
sapling: A young tree, not yet mature.
growingPlant: A growing plant of some kind.
cotton: A white and fluffy cotton plant, ready to be harvested.
tree: A large tree with a wealth of resources.
treeWithVines: A tree wrapped with thick vines, draped across it.
treeWithBerries: A tree covered with seemingly edible berries.

bareTree: A tree stripped of most of its leaves and branches.

palmTree: A tree with many palm leaves and usable wood.
barePalmTree: A tall palm tree stripped of its leaves.
cacti: Spined cacti, known for its edible fruit and needles.
deadBush: A sparse, dried out mass of branches.

litStoneWaterStill: A lit stone water still, desalinating water through evaporation.

litTorchStand: A torch stuck in the ground and lit on fire.
stoneAnvil: A stone anvil used primarily for metalworking and used in conjunction with a fire source.
acid: A neon-green ooze; boiling and bubbling into the ground.

woodenDoorOpen: An open door, allowing anything to enter.

woodenGateOpen: An opened gate, allowing anything to escape or enter.
poisonIvy: A creeping plant with leaves of three.

ironChest: An iron container for storing items and reducing food decay.
ornateWoodenChest: A decorative chest used for storing items and preserving perishables.
skeletalRemains: A pile of bones that appear to be stirring.

litClayKiln: A lit clay kiln, ready for firing items.
clayCampfire: An organized circle of clay bricks, used to contain a fire.
litClayCampfire: A lit fire inside an enclosure of clay bricks.
clayFurnace: A clay furnace for creating an enclosed high-temperature fire.
litClayFurnace: A lit clay furnance, ready to be used in production.
clayWaterStill: A clay water still, ready to be lit to desalinate water.
litClayWaterStill: A lit clay water still, desalinating water through evaporation.
sandstoneCampfire: An organized circle of sandstone, used to contain a fire.
litSandstoneCampfire: A lit fire inside an enclosure of sandstone.
sandstoneFurnace: A sandstone furnace for creating an enclosed high-temperature fire.
litSandstoneFurnace: A lit sandstone furnance, ready to be used in production.
sandstoneWaterStill: A sandstone water still, ready to be lit to desalinate water.
litSandstoneWaterStill: A lit sandstone water still, desalinating water through evaporation.
stoneKiln: A high-temperature fire enclosure made from stone.
litStoneKiln: A lit stone kiln, ready for firing items.
wroughtIronAnvil: A wrought iron anvil, used for blacksmithing with a fire source.
ironAnvil: An iron anvil used for metalworking. Used in addition with a fire source.

startFire: Used to start a fire. Use on campfires, furnaces, etc. to light them or on an empty tile. Using this action may require kindling, tinder and a fuel item in your inventory depending on the circumstance.
carve: Used to carve creature corpses or to remove objects attached to the ground.
setDown: Using this item will place it on top of whatever tile is present in your facing direction. This is different than just dropping the item. It can also be used to extinguish fires.
eat: Consumed on use. May provide benefits to hunger, thirst, health and stamina; however, may reduce them as well depending on the food.
drinkItem: Consumed on use. Will reduce your thirst; however, will provide negative effects when drinking sea/unpurified water.
rest: Used to rest for a period of time to regain health and stamina. You will stop resting when reaching full stamina.
sleep: Used to sleep for a period of time to regain health and stamina. Duration is based on camping skill and time of day. A bonus to all effects (including length) will be granted if facing a fire or lit object. Hunger and dehydration increase slower while sleeping.
heal: Consumed on use. Used to restore a varied amount of health.
dig: Used to dig up resources and items from the ground.
paddle: Used to travel over water without getting your feet wet. Your speed is not reduced in water while paddling.
gatherWater: Used to gather water into the item.
shoot: You can shoot arrows with this item.
cast: Find a fish in a body of water and attempt to cast your line or net to catch it.
traverseTheSea: Used to travel to new, unexplored lands, leaving behind your current surroundings.
sling: You can sling bullets with this item.
repair: Use while facing a damaged item to attempt to repair it. Success based on skill used to make the item.
decode: Used for attempting to read the map. Use by the treasure location to reveal how far or close you are.
read: Consumed on use. Reading usually provides useful knowledge.
reinforce: Consumed on use. Use while facing a damaged item to attempt to increase the overall maximum and minimum durability. Success based on skill used to make the item.
gather: Can be used directly to gather from an adjacent resource tile. Equipping this allows it to be automatically used when walking into resource tiles.
stokeFire: Used on a fire source to increase the strength of the flame.
pour: Pour on fire to extinguish the flames, pour inside a water still to begin water filtration, pour on a suitable plant to increase its health, or just simply empty out.
plant: Attempts to plant the item on the tile you are facing towards. Some plants may require certain ground types or conditions to be planted.
gatherTreasure: Attempt to gather a treasure in the vicinity of use based on a decoded treasure map. Range of gather is dependent on your mining skill.
ignite: Use this item on a fire source to start it on fire.
build: Attempt to construct or assemble the item on the tile you are facing towards.
openContainer: Using this will open it where you may drag and drop items to and from. Weight reduction and decay reduction bonuses may apply to items inside.
preserve: Used with food items to extend their life and decay rate.
openBottle: Consumed on use. Using this will open it, providing new and unknown items.
drinkCure: Consumed on use. Used to cure poisoning while sometimes providing other health benefits.
tellTime: Used to measure the time of day or night.
sailToCivilization: After collecting all the pieces of treasure, you can return to civilization and bask in the glory of your riches and fame. You can always return back to these lands afterwards.
transmogrify: Use while facing an equippable item to attempt to infuse with magical properties.
fire: Using a mixture of black powder along with a bullet, you may fire this weapon.
teleport: With a flick of the wand, teleport to a location in front of where you are facing.
extinguish: Douse the torch, extinguishing the flame.
drawMap: Draw a map using your skill in cartography of the surrounding area.
pourOnYourself: Liquid is consumed on use. Used to sooth burn injuries.
squeeze: Consumed on use. Spews a stream of fire in your facing direction.
healCreature: Consumed on use. Used to restore a varied amount of health to a creature.
rubClockwise: Rubbing this item manifests its effects to the holder.
rubCounterclockwise: Rubbing this item manifests its effects to the holder.
grasp: Used to pick-up items using another item for safety reasons such as grasping items in a fire.
till: Use while facing a tile you wish to till, granting it properties for better plant growth.

menuAboutDonators: An extra special thank you to all the early testers, donators, and other supporters.
menuAboutIntro: Wayward is a turn-based, top-down, wilderness survival roguelike currently in beta. It's brought to you by these fine folk:
menuAboutLibraries: Greenworks, Electron, TypeScript, Node.js, jQuery, jQueryUI, TSM, lz-string, jQuery contextMenu, jQuery UI Touch Punch, Pluralize, Fixedsys Excelsior
menuAboutLibrariesIntro: Wayward is made possible with the following projects:
menuAboutThanks: Richard 'Orillian' Hobson,Vlad 'vlsd' Seghete,Unstoppable Carl Olsen,Justin 'boxofrox' Charette,Frank Orechio,Drachlen,Joshua 'jday' Day,Oddmund 'oddmunds' Strømme
menuManageModsMessage: Open Steam Workshop to Install Mods
optionsAlternateContextMenuTooltip: If checked, right clicking items will display the item's menu instead of left click.
optionsAutoGatherTooltip: If checked, you will automatically gather when moving into resource tiles.
optionsAutoPickupTooltip: If checked, you will automatically pick-up items as you move on top of them.
optionsDeveloperLoggingTooltip: Enable verbose logging for language and mod debugging.
optionsDropOnGatherTooltip: If checked, you will automatically drop items under your character as you gather them.
optionsDropUnderYourselfTooltip: If checked, dropping items will place them at your feet instead of to the adjacent facing tile.
optionsEnableHintsTooltip: If checked, the game will display unseen hints when triggered.
optionsKeepSortActiveTooltip: If checked, your inventory will keep sorting automatically as you get items.
optionsMouseClickMovementTooltip: If checked, you will be able to tap or use your mouse to move on screen.
optionsProtectedCraftingItemsTooltip: If checked, equipped and quickslotted items won't be used in crafting.
optionsScreenshotModeTooltip: If checked, all user interface items will be hidden.
optionsSkipIntroTooltip: If checked, the game will skip the Unlok logo screen.
optionsWarnOnDangerousActionsTooltip: If checked, a confirmation screen will display when stepping over doodads or objects that could injure you.
optionsWarnWhenBreakingItemsTooltip: If checked, a confirmation screen will display when trying to craft using items that will break on failure.
optionsWorldTooltipsTooltip: If checked, hovering over non-empty tiles will reveal information in a tooltip so you don't have to inspect.
optionsZoomOnScrollTooltip: If checked, you will be able to zoom in and out in game using your mouse wheel/zoom gesture.

slime: A bouncing globule of animated gelatin. It isn't aware of your stirring.
jellyCube: An animated cube of gelatin. Its body jiggles to-and-fro as it moves towards you with hostile intent.
giantSpider: A gangly, frightful arachnid with the ability to poison you.
bear: A hulking carnivorous mammal attracted to your scent. A deadly foe without protection.
rabbit: A fast moving, peaceful herbivorous mammal. Useful for a good meal or as a pet.
snake: A slithering, poisonous reptile. Appears ambivalent to your encroachment.
giantRat: A rat of unusual size with sharp claws and piercing teeth. Keep at a distance without equipment.
rat: A small and scurrying rodent. Afraid of predators, it will try to escape your grasp.
vampireBat: A flying mammal with large rubbery wings. Appears to have a penchant for human blood.
greyWolf: A tall canid animal. Able to tear into flesh with vicious abandon.
imp: An odd hovering creature with thick wrinkled skin and sharp claws.
bogling: A foul, sulphurous-smelling writhing mass of vegetation, seemingly animated and alive.
livingRock: A massive pile of rocks and minerals that appears to be alive, or semi-aware at least.
shark: A large blood-thirsty cartilaginous sea creature. Its fin juts from the waters, taunting you.
zombie: A slow, but strong foul-smelling undead or diseased human. Appears to dislike the sun.
skeleton: An animated pile of human, or human-like bones.
pirateGhost: A glowing, ethereal visage of a pirate. It appears to be able to manifest a physical weapon to attack you.
timeSkitter: An unusual spider-like creature that appears to be able to move through solid objects and move at incredible speeds.
chicken: A flightless fowl that seems fearful of your presence. Produces feathers, eggs, meat, and more.
trapdoorSpider: A large spider that appeared from an underground dwelling as you stumbled over it.
fireElemental: A creature that is seemingly composed of only fire. Appears to spread fire and destruction in its wake.
cod: A common ocean fish, known for it's nutritionally-dense, flaky white flesh.
hobgoblin: An odd-looking humanoid. Dislikes your presence and appears to know how to use traps.
livingMushroom: A living mycological abomination. It appears to have a vengeful attitude towards you.
kraken: A wiry mass of thick tentacles, this lumbering sea-giant is angered by your existence.
blindfish: A cave-dwelling, sightless fish. Hard to see in detail within the murky depths.
harpy: A large and unusual avian creature. Hostile to your presence.
acidSpitterDemon: A small, but fierce demonic-looking creature with sharp claws. Appears to spit an acidic fluid.
skeletalMage: A robed, magic-casting skeletal humanoid. Its spell casting produces walls and teleportation.
clawWorm: A wriggling creature with a massive claw-mouth, spawned forth from the ground due to vibrations caused by your gathering.
drake: A massive flightless lizard-dragon with large scales and the ability to breath fire. A fearsome foe.
sandcat: A small, but ferocious feline that lives exclusively in desert areas.
lavaBeetle: A horned beetle with a large abdomen, filled with liquid magma.

welcomeToWayward:
Welcome to the Early Access version of Wayward! Wayward is currently in beta status and many things will change and improve over time. Hint windows like these will display as you play the game if enabled. You can disable automatic hints by clicking the button "Disable Hints" below or in the options. If you need further help or hints, visit the Steam Discussions forums.

If you want to keep up with Wayward, please visit the Wayward Blog or Subreddit.

Want to help Wayward? Spread the word, or follow us on one of the following sites: Facebook, Twitter, or IndieDB.
controls:
Keybinds can be changed under "Keybinds" in the options menu.

Window Shortcuts


{ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Escape)} = Close Menus and Windows, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Inventory)} = Inventory, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Equipment)} = Equipment, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Crafting)} = Crafting, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Help)} = Help, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Skills)} = Skills, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Messages)} = Messages, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Options)} = Options, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Actions)} = Actions, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Milestones)} = Milestones

Movement


To move, you can to use {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Up)}, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Left)}, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Down)}, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Right)} or by clicking/tapping on the game screen in the direction you want to move. To skip/pass a turn, or to pick up item(s) on the tile you are standing on, press the spacebar or left click/tap your character on the game screen.

Actions


Opening up the Actions menu will bring up a list of actions you can perform on the adjacent tile or object; for example, collecting a pineapple without needing to carve it up. This is also an alternate way to inspect a tile without needing to right click or hover on the game screen. Jumping is also selectable in the actions menu which can help you get out of tight spots, but watch out for the heavy stamina reduction; it's based on your current weight.

Using Items


To use an item, you may left click/tap it to bring up the item's menu. You will see a list of actions you can perform. Additionally, you are able to drag and drop an item into one of the quickslots. Press the number or hotkey ({ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.One)}, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Two)}, {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Three)}, etc.) that corresponds with which quickslot it is attached to perform the primary action for the item (unless changed).

Item Uses, Dropping and Information


Some items have more than one use - these will show up in the item's menu if available. You are able to right click an item to automatically drop it without going into the item menu. If you are facing a container, you will drop the item inside. You can shift + right click (or use "Drop All" from the menu) to drop multiple items of the same kind. You are also able to right click on the game screen to reveal information about what you are clicking on (referred to as "Inspect"), whether it be items, creatures, tiles, and more.

More Information


Hovering over elements on screen will typically reveal more information. Tool-tips will appear over items. Hovering over crafting items will highlight items used in the craft.

Item Management


Besides dragging and dropping items to your quickslots, you are also able to equip items in this fashion, provided it is an equipment item and fits in that slot. Dragging and dropping is also used to move items to your container window and inventory (shift + dragging will move all items of the same ). Additionally, right clicking an item in your equipment list, quickslots or container window will remove it from that slot.
corpseCarving: To harvest potential resources from corpses, you must carve them with a sharp item. Choose "Carve" from the item's menu or try moving it to a quickslot for ease of use.
doodads:
Doodads are considered objects attached to the ground like plants, piles of rocks, furnaces, campfires, etc. To collect them, you can do one of the following:

1. While facing the item, click or press the "Actions" hotkey with {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Actions)}, and select the "Collect Object With Hands" option.
2. Use an item with "Digging" such as a stone shovel.
3. Use an item with "Carving" such as a sharp rock.
4. Use an item with "Gather" such as a wooden pole.

Using your bare hands with no tool (option 1) can sometimes harm you. Using a tool (option 2/3/4) will decrease the durability of the item. Some objects may require a "Carving" tool such as corpses to harvest from them.
caves: Caves are the perfect place for hidden treasure, but first, they may need illumination with a torch to explore them further. Caves can be extremely dangerous and may require advanced armor and weaponry.
nightfall: If nightfall is approaching, find a safe area to camp out and prepare yourself for combat! Many tough creatures can prowl the night.
staminaReplenishment: If you find yourself getting exhausted, sleep or rest using a bedroll or hammock to regenerate stamina. You can also rest by going into the Actions menu and selecting "Rest"; however, resting with an item will produce better regenerative effects. Rest is different from sleep in that you will only ever rest until your stamina is maxed out. Alternatively, you may hold spacebar or click your character to skip turns.
healthProblems: If you find yourself injured, you replenish your health with food or healing-type items. Some status effects reduce your ability to regenerate your health including bleeding and poisoning. Alternatively, you can also try sleeping or resting to regenerate health.
bleeding: The bleeding status effect is usually the result of a low anatomy skill percentage while fighting a tough creature. Make sure to use a healing item to stop the bleeding, such as a bandage or tourniquet. Bleeding causes you to starve/dehydrate faster, regenerate stamina slower, and stops regeneration of health.
poisoned: Poisoning can happen from eating bad things or from some types of creatures. Make sure to use a curing item to cure the poison, such as medicinal water. Poisoning causes you to starve/dehydrate faster, regenerate stamina slower, and stops regeneration of health.
dehydration: There's many ways to get drinkable water, but unfortunately for you, the largest source of water, from the sea is nearly undrinkable in its raw form. You must desalinate the water through the use of a water still or flask before drinking it without adverse effects. Alternatively, you may seek out a fresh water source, such as from caves, small lakes, oases, swamps or ponds. Fresh water is drinkable in it's raw form without too many bad effects; however, you may still want to boil it for the best health results.
useATool: Gathering resources with your hands is difficult and harmful; try equipping or using a tool to eliminate the chance of injury. If you are mining or lumberjacking, your weapon(s) attack value will also help gather items faster. Blunt attack weapon will help you gather faster while mining, while slashing weapons will help you gather faster while lumberjacking.
durability: If you find one of your your tools, weapons or armor is close to breaking from overuse (highlighted with a red border), you will need to repair it using a hammer item or a grindstone. If you can't find or craft an item to repair it, it will soon break completely upon use.
death: Death is permanent. Although you may have died, all of the crafting recipes you have discovered will be ready on your next playthrough. Your milestones will also carry over, providing you multiple starting benefits.
consumingBadThings: Ow! Not all edible/drinkable objects should be consumed, at least not without facing the consequences. On the other hand, sometimes it's worth the risk to gain its other effects. Consuming bad things can sometimes result in poisoning.
fastPickup: You have just picked up an item from the ground. Sometimes there are multiple items on a tile. Pressing the spacebar or clicking on your character will gather items underneath you without moving.
bugs: Did you find an error? Would you kindly let us know about what happened, so that we may seek to stop this from happening to other players? You can do so by posting the issue in the Steam Discussions Bug Reports forum.
heldItems: Your left and right hand equipment slots are interchangeable. You can equip two weapons, two tools, two shields or any combination in between. With both the left and right hand options selected, you will use both hands (and whatever is equipped in each slot) in combat and in gathering. You can disable either the left or right hands to disable using that one in attacking and gathering. Disabling both will prevent you from attacking or gathering automatically.
milestones: Milestones are personalized goals and achievements. Each playthrough, you are given an amount to either discover or work towards. Milestones are saved after each playthrough or death. The more you have completed, the more starting skill and stat points you get, as well as more starting items.
burned: Lasting burn injuries and pain can be caused from stepping in an open flame without protection, or possibly other sources. Pouring liquid on yourself will soothe the injuries and pain. Alternatively, you can also take a swim in deep water. Keep swimming until the effect subsides. Being burned will stop you from regenerating health and can last awhile if untreated.
crafting:
Crafting is simple, but has many rules!

When hovering over an item in the crafting window, you will see which items will be used in the craft through a highlighted border that will appear around items in your inventory. You will also notice that you will use the first instance of a required item. Simply drag around the order of items in your inventory or use the sort to use different items in the craft.

Using items in a craft that have lower durability will affect the crafted item's durability. Additionally, using remarkable, exceptional or legendary items in a craft increases your chances to craft such an item. Decayable items (such as food) also gain decay bonuses from using higher quality items in the craft.

You can find new crafting recipes by gathering the required items in your inventory and by finding old instructional scrolls.
encumberance: The first level of encumberance will slow down your movement and reduce stamina regeneration. The second level, "overburdened" will physically hurt you as you will begin to take damage while trying to move. You can drop items from your inventory by right clicking, through the item's menu, or by dragging and dropping them on to the game screen.
dailyChallengeMode: Daily challenge mode is an extra difficult game mode with some unique game rules to add an extra challenge for skilled players. You can expect more creatures, a harder beginning of the game, and more. You cannot save your game in this mode. The world and randomization is unique per day, allowing multiple players to play in the same set of circumstances.
movingItems:
There are many ways to organize and move items in Wayward

1. Dragging and dropping: You can drag and drop items into a container window, quickslot, equipment slot, or directly on to the ground, by dragging it to the desired location. Dragging and dropping to the game screen will drop it in front of you, or inside a chest if you are facing one. Holding Shift while dragging will drag/drop all items of the same br />2. From the item's menu. Left clicking an item will display the item's menu with options to "Drop/Drop All", or if you have a container window open, will present you the option to "Move/Move All". If you click an item that has a special quality, additional options will be visible to Drop/Move all of the same quality.
3. Right clicking/dropping. You can right click any item in your inventory to drop it in front of you. This will automatically drop it into a chest if you are facing one. Holding shift while you right click will drop all of the same .

Note: You can change the default drop direction from the facing tile to underneath your character in the game's option menu.
craftingFailure:
All crafts in Wayward have a skill level assosiated with them. Hovering over each craft will reveal the item's craft skill level. These levels going from easiest to harder are: simple, intermediate, advanced, and expert.

Trying to craft an item with a higher skill level than your own crafting skill can sometimes result in failure. Your chance to successfully craft the item raises as your skills increase. If the item's skill level appears in orange, you will have a low chance at success for crafting that item. Each unsucessful attempt at crafting will reduce the durability of each item involved in the craft.
reputation:
These lands are mysterious and seem to react to your presence and actions. Crafting and using items, killing creatures, and performing skills will all effect your malignity and benignity, and thus your reputation. The lower your reputation becomes, the more challenging survival becomes. Having a high reputation assumes you are peaceful, and these lands will act in kindness towards you by not allowing more difficult creatures to spawn. Certain peaceful actions may increase your reputation and benignity such as gardening or planting mushrooms and plants. Travelling away to other lands using boats can significantly increase your reputation as well.

Caves will always feature the same creatures, regardless of reputation and during the night, if your reputation is below 0, some very dangerous creatures can spawn.
interface:
The windowed interface in Wayward is completely customizable. You can move them around as you see fit, and resize them to expand the information that is viewable. Move them around by dragging the title bar of each window. Resize them by dragging the corner of the window.

If you are still having issues finding certain items within the inventory or crafting windows, try using the filter or sorting features.
creatureTaming:
Violence is sometimes not the best option! Besides running away from a confrontation with the hostile island creatures, another option is to attempt to tame them. To attempt creature taming, simply face the creature and select "Tame" from your action menu (opened with {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Actions)}).

Sometimes attempting to calm the creature directly will not be enough. You can also attempt to offer an item to creature. Simply face the creature, open a item's menu and select "Offer". If the creature likes or wants the item, it will become tamed.
combat:
Engaging in combat with creatures may not be the best option. In Wayward, you are free to attempt to kill creatures as well as tame or flee from them. The strategy is up to you!

Many skills play an important role in your successfulness at slaying the creature. Open your skills window using {ui.getStringForKeyBind(KeyBind.Skills)} and view the hints provided when hovering over skills such as tactics and parrying. Skills are not the only important factor when battling creatures. Your weaponry and armaments also play a role. The combat messages will tell you of your effectivenesses and inadequacies when in combat.
